filename: Re_ [EXTERNAL] Re_ Cengage Learning Permission Request_ Harold Cohen, AARON Gijon, 2007- Image for Understanding Art_ Fichner-Rathus - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2025-05-19 1242.eml
subject:
Re: [EXTERNAL] Re: Cengage Learning Permission Request: Harold Cohen,
 AARON Gijon, 2007- Image for Understanding Art/ Fichner-Rathus
message_text:
Dear Mr Devanathan, as far as I can tell, the image you want to reproduce
is not from the Gijon series. Moreover, AARON Gijon was meant for
projection, not reproduction. If the author wishes to work with the Harold
Cohen Trust to select an image that is appropriate for her book, please ask
her to get in touch with me at this email address.

filename: Re_ FW_ Cengage Learning Permission Request_ Harold Cohen, AARON Gijon, 2007- Image for Understanding Art_ Fichner-Rathus - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2025-04-10 1726.eml
subject:
Re: FW: Cengage Learning Permission Request: Harold Cohen, AARON
 Gijon, 2007- Image for Understanding Art/ Fichner-Rathus
message_text:
Hi Micah, thanks for getting in touch. Gijon is a computer program. Last
year, the Whitney bought one copy of an edition (five, if I remember
rightly) for its collection. It isn't clear what Cengage wants. Imagery
is one thing, code another. It would be contrary to the spirit of our
agreement with WMAA to let Cengage have the code. I am certainly willing to
talk with them, and I appreciate your offer to put us in touch. Thanks,

filename: Re_ introductions - Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2025-05-19 0210.eml
subject: Re: introductions
cc:
Paul Cohen <team@haroldcohentrust.org>, 
	Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>, 
	"Moss, Ceci" <clmoss@ucsd.edu>
message_text:
Hi Everyone,Thanks for the introductions. I will let Paul chime in regarding any potential San Diego visit by him. If you have a timeline or sorts, even a vague one, that would be helpful.
Thomas Machnik — Art Studio Manager — The Harold Cohen Trust
 On Saturday, May 17, 2025 at 08:48:54 AM PDT, Nina Karavasiles <nkaravasiles@gmail.com> wrote: 

 Hey all,I'm very excited about all of this and can manipulate my schedule around, perhaps Paul's, who I'm guessing is the furthest away. When will you be in town?Nina


Dear Ceci, Thomas, Paul, Nina and trust,

Just taking a moment here to make introductions between us all. Ceci 
Moss is my dear colleague and director of the Mandeville Art Gallery at 
UCSD where I serve as an advisory board member. Thomas is Art Studio 
Manager of the Harold Cohen Trust, Nina is a former student of Harold's, 
UCSD MFA and of course Paul is Harold's son and a computer scientist of 
many roles including dean at Pitt and DARPA alum. (Side note: Paul, we 
started this convesation with the fact that Harold has been part of our 
curriculum in AI arts history units in our vis 142 class since I started 
here in 2004, a class in which we also discuss DARPA! There are so many 
neat serendipitous connections here... Nina is a backcountry neighbor of 
mine and knows my wife Paula from Warner Springs, where Paula is the 
public school art teacher... they have worked together in the past:-)

So that conversation has been about UCSD's recent attempts and plans to 
honor Harold's legacy here. The idea that had emerged was that we meet 
up in person and discuss further. So I am just throwing out intros at 
this point, and looking for thoughts as to a time line for meeting!

cheers all,
Brett Stalbaum

filename: Re_ Quick question re Harold Cohen data for Sothebys - Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2024-10-10 0331.eml
subject: Re: Quick question re Harold Cohen data for Sothebys
cc:
Cohen Paul <paulrcohen@gmail.com>, 
	Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>, 
	Askarova Norton Mila <m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com>
message_text:
Hi Robert,
Well, we have a dilemma. I actual see two additional options. I don't necessarily have the final word as we should get Paul's input. In order of my preference from most preferred to least, I list them below. Just want to note that knowing what I now know, I would not have sent this one. 

Preference from most preferred to least1) Pull the work from the auction2) Sell the print but without the NFT or sell NFT without print
3) Use your 2nd option with a minor changeYour second option is to leave the certificate as is but add a note. I suggest changing the note on the certificate to, "this is the earliest known file the estate has for this work."  I would leave out, "the descriptor file was not saved until 2003". We might consider, "the earliest known descriptor file for this work has a 2003 timestamp."
4) is the one about changing the certificate to 2003. This is probably the most appropriate thing to do because it reflects reality. But we are concerned about the implications for the collectors. And because of this, I included the option of pulling the work from the auction or selling the print but not the NFT with it. 

Honestly, except for #1 I am a bit uncomfortable with all of them. Maybe in general an auction is not the proper venue for selling works that include signing errors. Maybe in those cases it would be better to have a one-on-one conversation with the collector on the reality and provide a more complete story of the work. And maybe this is what we should do regarding this work.

I do have an additional concern regarding this work (with respect to generating a certificate) in that we have some evidence that a 2/3 and 3/3 might have been made and as of yet, I do not know how they were signed. I do know that in our 2002 - 2004 catalog (the one I showed you when you visited)... in there the work is documented as being 2003. So again everything points to the work being 2003 and that Harold made an error. 

If we keep the claim of the print as being signed as 2002 without explanation, internally we will have implications as well. And these implications may actually out way the concern of the implications related to collectors. For example, if we want to make our 2002 - 2004 catalog in its current or expanded form more widely available, the catalog will not jive with the certificate. And in any other instance whereby Harold referred to this work (this includes multiple Powerpoint presentations, speeches and the like) the confusion is only exasperated due to that one number in pencil being written as a 2 and not a 3.
I know this is on the eve of the auction and I would have preferred I didn't send this one. And like you mention though not in these exact terms, this work belongs to the misfits group. I don't know we can pull this work on the eve of the auction but that is my preference. But I am open to hear what Paul things about all this.
Tom

 On Wednesday, October 9, 2024, 8:52:46 AM PDT, Robert Norton <robert@verisart.com> wrote: 

 Thanks Tom for double checking all this.  Appreciate that all this takes time and it’s sometimes hard to determine what happened so long ago.
Regarding this work, we now have two options:
1) We create a new certificate for the print and change the date from 2002 to 2003.  The problem with this is that the collector would receive the print and may then ask why the year says 2002 whereas the record says 2003 and this may create further confusion and invite further scrutiny regarding dates written on other prints.  I think we would want to avoid this as we are looking to build a trusted market for this works.  We would also need to destroy the already minted NFT which states a production year of 2002 which is what is supplied although the file metadata does say 2003.
2) We leave the certificate for the print as it stands which states it was produced in 2002.  We add a note to the certificate for the NFT to say this is the earliest known file the estate has for this work and say that the descriptor file was not saved until 2003.  The benefit with this is we don't have to re-mint or re-issue the NFT or the certificate and we can simply amend the certificate for the NFT to reflect the above.
I suspect there may be other cases we come across when we put together the catalog raisonne and it may be better to include all works together in a series of changes the estate agrees upon than to introduce all this know on the eve, so to speak, of the selling exhibition with Sotheby’s.
We will do whatever you think is best but from our perspective we think Option 2 is preferable at this stage.
Grateful for your thoughts and guidance on this.
Best
Robert
Robert NortonCEO & co-founderVerisart


 Dear Robert,

filename: Re_ Viewing in LA - 29th Oct - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2024-10-27 1133.eml
subject: Re: Viewing in LA - 29th Oct
message_text:
Folks, here's a thought about strategy for folios. Please let me know what
you think:

Define a folio to be a collection of prints that have some coherence (e.g.,
AG1 - AG12)

Define a reference folio to be a folio that can be used as reference
material for reprinting or by scholars etc. Note that a reference folio
can contain damaged works provided the damage does not prevent the
reference material being used as intended. Note also that a reference
folio need not be signed.

As with individual works, we should *never* sell the reference folio.

That's the easy part. Now the harder part concerns selling work from
nonreference folios. Here we need guidance from Mila. I think we could
make the argument that we should not break up the last of a folio, unless
the prices warrant it or there is no prospect of selling the entire folio
as a unit. Suppose we have two copies of a folio (e.g., two undamaged
copies of each of the 12 prints in AG), then I would argue that we can sell
from one of these folios.

What do you think?

filename: Harold Cohen sale - Douglas Dodds <douglas_dodds@hotmail.com> - 2024-10-18 1614.eml
subject: Harold Cohen sale
message_text:
Hello both

Hope you're keeping well. I've just seen the Sotheby's catalogue for the Harold Cohen sale and thought I should get in touch.

 I see that they've now updated the online description for 0305-08, which was incorrect until recently. For information I acquired a copy of this for the museum in 2005, along with a copy of 0305-03 (no. 2 of 5 - not in the Sotheby's catalogue).

https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O114804/0305-08-print-cohen-harold/

[https://framemark.vam.ac.uk/collections/2010EL6972/full/!600,/0/default.jpg]<https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O114804/0305-08-print-cohen-harold/>
0305-08 | Cohen, Harold | V&A Explore The Collections<https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O114804/0305-08-print-cohen-harold/>
Digital inkjet print, abstracted floral imagery in yellow and green, by Harold Cohen, printed United States, 2003
collections.vam.ac.uk

https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O114802/0305-03-print-cohen-harold/
[https://framemark.vam.ac.uk/collections/2010EL6973/full/!600,/0/default.jpg]<https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O114802/0305-03-print-cohen-harold/>
0305-03 | Cohen, Harold | V&A Explore The Collections<https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O114802/0305-03-print-cohen-harold/>
Digital inkjet print, abstracted floral imagery in pink and blue, by Harold Cohen, printed United States, 2003
collections.vam.ac.uk

Both are illustrated in the small Digital Pioneers catalogue produced for the V&A's show in 2009 (nos. 41-42). 0305-03 was also exhibited in a V&A exhibition entitled Prints Now and is illustrated in the accompanying book, p. 11.

Several of the other works in the Sotheby's sale have appeared in print or online too, but I don't know whether copies of any of them were ever acquired by anyone.

Best wishes

Doug

www.douglasdodds.org

filename: Re_ Harold Cohen sale - Douglas Dodds <douglas_dodds@hotmail.com> - 2025-04-01 1157.eml
subject: Re: Harold Cohen sale
message_text:
Hello Paul

Nice to hear from you. Of course, I’d be very glad to contribute to this in any way I can - sounds fascinating, and entirely appropriate too. So, do count me in!

Do you have Pip’s email at UCL? It’s p.laurenson@ucl.ac.uk<mailto:p.laurenson@ucl.ac.uk>

Best wishes, and good luck with the application!

Doug

<http://www.douglasdodds.org/>
Douglas Dodds, Independent Curator, formerly Senior Curator, V&A<http://www.douglasdodds.org/>
douglasdodds.org<http://www.douglasdodds.org/>
[favicon_d1_res.ico]<http://www.douglasdodds.org/>



﻿
Hi Doug, first I must apologize for a very close deadline. I just learned of this opportunity from the Schmidt Sciences<https://schmidtsciences.smapply.io/prog/humanities_and_artificial_intelligence_virtual_institute_havi_/> foundation. A few months ago I proposed to one of the LLM companies a “21st Century Catalogue Raisonne” built around Harold. That proposal looks like it will go forward, but slowly, so I am proposing the same to Schmidt, except I want to build something not just for Harold’s CR but for any artist who wants it. I am trying to assemble a consortium of experts on very short notice and I am hoping that I can tempt you to participate. Christiane Paul and Mila are on board, as are Bre Pettis and Tom Machnik. I’m trying to get in touch with Pip Laurensen but no luck so far.

The pre-proposal is due on Friday. It’s only three pages and is well in hand. I wouldn’t need anything from you until they accept the pre-proposal and give us 60 days to write the full proposal. I have attached the original proposal to the LLM company (please don’t share it) to give you a sense of what the Schmidt pre-proposal will say.

I do hope you can participate, I think this could be a really interesting project.

Thanks! —Paul



Hi Paul

Nice to hear from you, and I'm glad the information was useful. I imagine it's a nightmare tracking everything Harold produced.

I'll be away for a few days from 24-27 Nov but hopefully we might still be able to meet up!

Best wishes

Doug

www.douglasdodds.org<http://www.douglasdodds.org/>
________________________________





Hi Doug, thanks for your email. I hope you are keeping well. Perhaps we'll bump into each other around the Electric Dreams show? I plan to be there for a couple of days.

Thanks for your eagle eye on these prints. The whole experience has been interesting and edifying. Harold didn't keep the best records, so Tom Machnik, Harold's studio manager, cc'd here, labored long to track down editions and provenance. Your notes on the above are super helpful, thank you!

Looking forward to seeing you in late November if you are around.

We have an internal document claiming that the BBC aired a show titled “Tomorrow’s World” on or around March 22, 2000. Our understanding is that Harold Cohen’s AARON was included in this program. filename: Research Question - Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2025-06-05 1837.eml
subject: Research Question
message_text:
Hi Christiane, 
Happy Thursday and happy June already! I hope you can help me with a question. From time to time I work on researching where Cohen’s works are. Harold left behind lists of museums and other entities but did not necessarily document what those works were. Also in the case of Robert Hendel and others who may have had the original an original work they then donate to a museum. Unless they notify us we are not aware of the transfer. Therefore, the list doesn’t necessarily help. 
I can (and do from time to time) contact various institutions. Some institutions have the ability to search on the website others do not. Are you aware of some sort of database for museums and/or other institutions that may have what I am looking for — name lists of Cohen works? Also, when I do contact a museum, when I don’t have a personal contact, I rarely make any headway. Do you have any suggestions on what department or what position I ask for? Or any other suggestions? I’d appreciate you thoughts.
Hope all is well,
Tom

filename: Re_ Canvas shipping list - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2024-12-06 1103.eml
subject: Re: Canvas shipping list
message_text:
Hi George, sorry for my delayed reply. My recollection of the pricing
discussion is similar to yours, but not quite the same, and my recollection
of our strategy might be a bit different as well.

I recall that the pricing discussion changed from "size-based" to
"quality-based". Mila pointed out that some mid-sized works are better
than others. She asked why some should not be priced at X, where X is
higher than 150K. FWIW, I think the four mid-sized works cited in your
email aren't the best, so I won't argue that their price should be higher.
But if we were planning to show, say, 2475 or 2476 etc. then I'd agree with
Mila: These are better paintings.

As to strategy, we discussed several but I don't remember which we settled
on. At one point in the conversation, Mila suggested not sending large
works to the art fairs but holding them back. At another point we
discussed sending a mix of mid-size and large work. I think we all agreed
that small canvases are anomalous and will be held back. You seem to be
suggesting sending a mix of mid-sized and large works priced at 150K and
300K, respectively. Do you intend that the mid-sized works for the fairs
will be the ones you mention in your message, or were you suggesting only
that these works should be priced at 150K as our first tranche irrespective
of where they are shown for sale?

Changing subject, any further thoughts on us purchasing Tom Gruber's
paintings?

Incidentally, I got an alert from Artsy this morning. Is this just a
random spasmodic mailing or have we started to market the early work?
https://www.artsy.net/artwork/67530c4392b8875af5adaa93?utm_medium=email&utm_source=braze&utm_campaign=alert&utm_term=v2

filename: Re_ AARON painting appraisal recommendation request - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2025-02-06 1157.eml
subject: Re: AARON painting appraisal recommendation request
cc:
Paul Cohen <team@haroldcohentrust.org>, aaron@aaronshome.com, 
	Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com>, George Lionel Barker <george@gazelliarthouse.com>
message_text:

purposes so the appraisals were low and the recent increase in prices
wasn't reflected. It might be more accurate to ask the Gazelli Art House,
which represents the Harold Cohen Trust, for a reference for an appraiser.

filename: Re_ Request for Extant video_audio of the British artist Harold Cohen (1928-2016) - Archive Requests External <archiverequestsexternal@bbc.co.uk> - 2024-01-11 0948.eml
subject:
RE: Request for Extant video/audio of the British artist Harold Cohen
 (1928-2016)
cc: Sara Nishi <nishisara@gmail.com>, Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>,kanoko nishi 西鹿乃子<littledeerofthewest@googlemail.com>, Laura Green <laura@gazelliarthouse.com>
message_text:
Dear Thomas

The Open University programme with the course code M206/TV10 has the BBC programme number FOUM535A and is subtitled “Artware”, this was transmitted on 29 April 1997 (NB not 24 April).

The Tate Gallery item does appear to have been filmed in the Gallery itself, there is no indication on the BBC paperwork exactly when the filming took place but it is likely to have been on the day of transmission or very shortly before.

Kind regards

Andrew




Cc: Sara Nishi <nishisara@gmail.com>; Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>; kanoko nishi 西鹿乃子 <littledeerofthewest@googlemail.com>; Laura Green <laura@gazelliarthouse.com>


Dear Andrew,
Thank you for the list. I know it is not much but every little be helps. I am familiar with "It'll Never Work" as we have this programme on VHS tape. We also have a VHS tape of "Knowledge Talks: The Turing Test" but I did not have the date of the work so the date was very helpful. In regards to "Open University: Artware..." We have a tape with a printed label. Some of the text is difficult to read but it might read as:
A.LAW BBC OPEN UNIVERSITY ?OUM535A M206/TV10
This is a PAL format VHS and since we only have NTSC equipment I have yet to view it. There is a date of on the tape being 17/1/97. Based on this limited information, can you tell if this is the same programme as the Open University 24/04/97? If not, might you be able tell me what this programme is about?

In regards to the Newsnight 07/06/83 programme. This the first time to learn of this one. Cohen was in London around that time for a show at the Tate. Can you tell if the "Item on Computer Art" was filmed at the Tate Museum on our about the date of airing? In other words, is there a way to know where & when the filming took place?

filename: Re_ Research Question - Christiane Paul <Christiane_Paul@whitney.org> - 2025-06-06 1229.eml
subject: Re: Research Question
message_text:
Hi Tom,
So nice to hear from you! It's been the dream of curators, museum staff, and the digital art world, in particular, to have an archive or meta-data interoperability to be able to trace an artist's work across institutional collections. Sadly, initiatives so far haven't gone anywhere, so we are all stuck with tracing works in individual collections. The registrar or staff in the registrar's department are typically the best people to contact.

When it comes to private collectors donating to institutions or reselling, the situation tends to be even worse. I think in this case the use of NFTs as certificate of authenticity could play a valuable role  at least the transfer of a work from one owner to another could be transparently traced.

I'm sorry I can't be more helpful.
All the best,
Christiane

Christiane Paul

Curator of Digital Art

Whitney Museum of American Art
99 Gansevoort Street
New York, NY 10014

________________________________



Cc: George Lionel Barker <george@gazelliarthouse.com>; Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>

filename: Re_ Quick question re Harold Cohen data for Sothebys - Robert norton <robert@verisart.com> - 2024-10-10 0411.eml
subject: Re: Quick question re Harold Cohen data for Sothebys
cc:
Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>,
 Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>,
 Mila Askarova Norton <m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com>
message_text:
Thanks Tim for explaining all this.  The work is not being auctioned by Sothebys - rather it is a selling exhibition on show in NY and with fixed prices so we will be able to discuss all this with the collector if we choose.  BestRobert On Oct 10, 2024, at 08:31, Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> wrote:﻿
 Hi Robert,Well, we have a dilemma. I actual see two additional options. I don't necessarily have the final word as we should get Paul's input. In order of my preference from most preferred to least, I list them below. Just want to note that knowing what I now know, I would not have sent this one. Preference from most preferred to least1) Pull the work from the auction2) Sell the print but without the NFT or sell NFT without print3) Use your 2nd option with a minor changeYour second option is to leave the certificate as is but add a note. I suggest changing the note on the certificate to, "this is the earliest known file the estate has for this work."  I would leave out, "the descriptor file was not saved until 2003". We might consider, "the earliest known descriptor file for this work has a 2003 timestamp."4) is the one about changing the certificate to 2003. This is probably the most appropriate thing to do because it reflects reality. But we are concerned about the implications for the collectors. And because of this, I included the option of pulling the work from the auction or selling the print but not the NFT with it. Honestly, except for #1 I am a bit uncomfortable with all of them. Maybe in general an auction is not the proper venue for selling works that include signing errors. Maybe in those cases it would be better to have a one-on-one conversation with the collector on the reality and provide a more complete story of the work. And maybe this is what we should do regarding this work.I do have an additional concern regarding this work (with respect to generating a certificate) in that we have some evidence that a 2/3 and 3/3 might have been made and as of yet, I do not know how they were signed. I do know that in our 2002 - 2004 catalog (the one I showed you when you visited)... in there the work is documented as being 2003. So again everything points to the work being 2003 and that Harold made an error. If we keep the claim of the print as being signed as 2002 without explanation, internally we will have implications as well. And these implications may actually out way the concern of the implications related to collectors. For example, if we want to make our 2002 - 2004 catalog in its current or expanded form more widely available, the catalog will not jive with the certificate. And in any other instance whereby Harold referred to this work (this includes multiple Powerpoint presentations, speeches and the like) the confusion is only exasperated due to that one number in pencil being written as a 2 and not a 3.I know this is on the eve of the auction and I would have preferred I didn't send this one. And like you mention though not in these exact terms, this work belongs to the misfits group. I don't know we can pull this work on the eve of the auction but that is my preference. But I am open to hear what Paul things about all this.Tom

 On Wednesday, October 9, 2024, 8:52:46 AM PDT, Robert Norton <robert@verisart.com> wrote:

 Thanks Tom for double checking all this.  Appreciate that all this takes time and it’s sometimes hard to determine what happened so long ago.Regarding this work, we now have two options:1) We create a new certificate for the print and change the date from 2002 to 2003.  The problem with this is that the collector would receive the print and may then ask why the year says 2002 whereas the record says 2003 and this may create further confusion and invite further scrutiny regarding dates written on other prints.  I think we would want to avoid this as we are looking to build a trusted market for this works.  We would also need to destroy the already minted NFT which states a production year of 2002 which is what is supplied although the file metadata does say 2003.2) We leave the certificate for the print as it stands which states it was produced in 2002.  We add a note to the certificate for the NFT to say this is the earliest known file the estate has for this work and say that the descriptor file was not saved until 2003.  The benefit with this is we don't have to re-mint or re-issue the NFT or the certificate and we can simply amend the certificate for the NFT to reflect the above.I suspect there may be other cases we come across when we put together the catalog raisonne and it may be better to include all works together in a series of changes the estate agrees upon than to introduce all this know on the eve, so to speak, of the selling exhibition with Sotheby’s.We will do whatever you think is best but from our perspective we think Option 2 is preferable at this stage.Grateful for your thoughts and guidance on this.BestRobert
Robert NortonCEO & co-founderVerisart<verisart-certified-signature (1).gif>

filename: Re_ Quick question re Harold Cohen data for Sothebys - Robert Norton <robert@verisart.com> - 2024-10-11 0940.eml
subject: Re: Quick question re Harold Cohen data for Sothebys
cc:
Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com>,
 Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>,
 Askarova Norton Mila <m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com>,
 Chow Natalia <natalia@verisart.com>
message_text:
Thanks Paul for your input and good to have an agreed direction.

With your agreement, we will change the year if production from 2002 to 2003 and add a note to the COA for the print with the following text:

“The Harold Cohen Trust notes that the artist has signed this print as 2002 but has concluded this was an error. The file name 0311-32 refers to the year 2003, the month November and the 32nd Aaron generated work in that month.'

We will also need to burn the existing NFT and re-mint it with the correct date. Please let me know if this works and I’ll inform Sotheby’s.

Best

Robert

Robert Norton
CEO & co-founder
Verisart <http://www.verisart.com/>

￼

> On Oct 10, 2024, at 19:51, Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> wrote:
> 
> Robert, Tom, sorry for being out of touch,I just got to Boston.
> 
> I think our best option is to tell the whole story. If we were stamp collectors, errors like this would be worth a fortune. The story as I understand it leaves no doubt that "2002" was an error. Here's the evidence:
> 
> The left side of the print identifies the work as 03-11-32 (Tom, correct me if I misremember the order of the pairs), which means 2003, November, 32nd print of the year
> Another print in the sale was printed at nearly the same time. On the left it says 03-11-35. On the right it says 2003.
> Harold compiled a catalog of work in 2004. In that catalog, the print is given the date 2003.
> We might be able to find an exhibition catalog that shows the print and gives it the date 2003. Tom is looking now.
> Most importantly, Aaron simply couldn't have made this image in 2002. Tom's research shows that potted plants happened in 2003 and, notably, shadows didn't appear until the summer of 2003.
> All this evidence and Harold's well-known inability to keep track of days and dates leave no doubt in my mind that "2002" is an error. The Trust can stand confidently behind this account. Far from raising questions about the dates of the other prints, the research that went into resolving this anomaly should convince Sotheby's and collectors that we are very serious about the dates.
>

filename: Canvas shipping list - George Lionel Barker <george@gazelliarthouse.com> - 2024-12-03 0602.eml
subject: Canvas shipping list
message_text:
Dear both,

Please find enclosed a link to our proposed shipping list for the
figurative canvases that are currently in Encinitas, to be sent alongside
the unrolled works in Tom's previous email:
https://privateviews.artlogic.net/2/f5fcb1f56f9ce5a013b84a/

Can we please also have the remaining Painting Machine works you have there
too? New pricing TBC.

We agreed to set the retail price of HC2477, HC2448, HC4426 and HC4427 at
£150,000. I think it would be beneficial to sell one work in the new year,
leaving three for the fairs.

The plan was to market some of them at Dallas Art Fair and Armoury NYC in
2025, alongside a selection of other Cohen works. At this stage, we would
still need to be invited/apply to both fairs, and the longer term goal is
Frieze and Basel in 2026.

Are we ok to price the first available large one at £300,000? And then
increase the price by 100k until the third one is £500,000? It looks like
there are 15 or so large ones, compared with 10 medium sized ones.

Regarding a cursory stock-check of all figurative canvases, both in London
and California, I have counted 29 in total. There are 4 not listed on AL,
but found via a PDF on our shared drive (attached). We are hoping that
Tom's rolled canvases yield some more.

I think we'd need to get the shipping process up and running as soon as we
can.

Looking forward to hearing from you,

George

*GAZELLI ART HOUSE*

filename: Fwd_ NBC News interview request about AI art - Paul Cohen <team@haroldcohentrust.org> - 2025-02-22 1903.eml
subject: Fwd: NBC News interview request about AI art
message_text:
Hi Paul,

Not sure what to do about this email from NBC or future emails like this.
Previous to us having the haroldcohentrust account, media requests would
have gone to GAH first. I am now in the habit of checking this email weekly
but that may not be often enough.

They were or may still be looking for an interview with respect to this
month’s Christie’s AI Auction. The email may be a form type letter as it
sounds like they don’t know Harold has passed. I know there is controversy
surrounding some of the works at auction. Especially programs scanning
previous works and then not crediting the artists who created them. In
my view, AARON seems to be on the opposite spectrum.

Anyway, how should we respond?

Tom

message_text:

Tom
 On Thursday, June 5, 2025 at 09:01:15 AM PDT, George Lionel Barker <george@gazelliarthouse.com> wrote: 

 Hey Tom, 
Thanks so much for getting back to me, I appreciate it. 
Is the good friend of Harold you spoke to interested in selling? It's important for us to try and avoid the risk of Cohen's work appearing in public auction, and we'd be delighted to have a conversation with them about a possible sale. Either way, it's great that you've had the chance to look through the inventory, and discovered one of the panels from 'The Age of Intelligent Machines'! 
It has been a real pleasure working with you all over the past few years. It's been a personal point of pride to have been involved in helping expand the audience for Harold's work. 
Thanks again Tom, and everyone :) 

GAZELLI ART HOUSE
LONDONThe Way Forward: Derek Boshier and the Sixties
BAKU Spring Flow

If you are not an intended recipient, you are hereby notified that you have either received this message in error or through interception, and that any review, use, distribution, copying or disclosure of this message and/or its attachments or parts thereof is strictly prohibited and is subject to criminal and civil penalties with appropriate national legislation.

 Hi George,Good to hear from you. Sorry about the delay. Yesterday, I was at a good friend of Harold’s yesterday doing inventory of their collection of Cohen/AARON works which turns out the collection spans the time period from 1971 to 2012. The 1971 work is one of the original LACMA Maze drawings that were executed and mail out as invitations to the 1972 show. Another important discovery is that they have one of the panels from an important piece titled “The Age of Intelligent Machines (1986).” We have two of the panels in the studio but I have long wondered why one was missing. Now I know where that is! 
In any case, you are interested in more recent works. The only information I have of 1991-1999 works being in collections is for Robert Hendel and Frank Dictrich. You are right "Stephanie and Friend” is with Whitney now but originally was with Robert Hendel’s collection. In addition to Stephanie and Friend, Hendel has or had multiple works from this time period. My understanding is that he was ok with the Whitney taking the other Cohen/AARON works in his collection but the Whitney does not accept entire private collections or something to that effect. So it is possible that additional works from this time period in his collection were sent to other museums.  Dictrich seems to have had only one work a 1997 piece and I don’t have any info on who he is yet. I don’t see any museums listed. I will look some more today but want to get this to you sooner than later,
I understand, your last official day is tomorrow. Feel free to keep in touch beyond that time. I wish you much luck in your future and look forward to the time with our paths will cross again.
Tom
 On Wednesday, June 4, 2025 at 04:54:13 AM PDT, George Lionel Barker <george@gazelliarthouse.com> wrote: 

 Hey Tom, 
I've been looking back on your fantastic research, and there is so much useful information there - specifically about the murals and the painting machine series. Thank you so much! The resources are invaluable. 
I've got what will hopefully be a quick question. Do you know which museums have AARON/Cohen's figurative works on canvas in their collection? Similar series and period as this one in the Whitney collection (Stephanie and Friends) https://whitney.org/collection/works/67981 
I don't think there are many, but please let me know? 
Looking forward to hearing from you, 
George Barker 

GAZELLI ART HOUSE

filename: Re_ Just touching base - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2025-04-09 1018.eml
subject: Re: Just touching base
message_text:
Hi Bob, please forgive my long delay in writing to you. I am still
bouncing back and forth between Pittsburgh and Boston, and we just listed
the house in Pittsburgh and are renovating the one in Boston. This is my
16th or 17th house but the work gets harder as I get older!

Anyway, half my stuff is here and the other half there, and it's always the
wrong half. The Whitney drawings that I promised you are in Pittsburgh and
I am in Boston until the end of the month, but I will send them as soon as
I get back.

In other news...Mila Askarova and I are trying to get the exhibition to
Asia, and I have a "sort of promise" from an LLM company to provide some
sponsorship, so we're hopeful. It has been pretty rough since January, as
you can imagine, and now everything is tinged with fear and considerations
that have nothing to do with art. Other things: We tried a NFT sale
through Sotheby's but it was not successful. Sotheby's couldn't make their
minds up: Initially it was to be a NFT experiment, but then they
emphasized the physical works rather than the digital versions, and
eventually it became a sale of prints masquerading as an NFT drop. So
you'll be relieved to hear that NFTs are not in our immediate future!
Also, Gazelli has a really strong booth at the Dallas Art Fair and it's
already getting press
<https://www.papercitymag.com/arts/dallas-art-fair-year-17-what-to-collect/>
.

More recently I have been reimagining the catalog raisonne. I have
attached a short proposal to the Schmidt Foundation; I hope you find it
interesting. They probably won't fund it because their focus is on
humanities, but the modern catalog raisonne extends beyond the visual arts
and I hope they see that.

Lastly, I am sure I have asked you this before but my memory isn't what it
was: I think I need to set up an LLC to be owned by the Harold Cohen Trust
so that I can pay Tom and make distributions to the heirs without incurring
a personal tax burden, but I really need professional advice. The people
I've spoken with in Pittsburgh won't touch it because the Trust is
registered in California, so things are at a standstill, which is a
problem. Do you have any ideas about how to move forward?

filename: Airport Visit - Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2025-04-18 0255.eml
subject: Airport Visit
message_text:
Hi Paul,I was able to meet with Daniel at the San Diego Airport today and he took me on a tour showing me the spaces. I took some photos which I will upload tomorrow. In general there are two different kind of spaces. One being flat walls — or nearly flat — and the other being big glass cases set into the wall space. The flat spaces could possibly accommodate projection but I am not quite sure because people would be walking by. Daniel seems to think it would be doable so maybe it is. The glass cases are approximately 8 ft high although one might be a bit shorter. The width varies with the biggest around 16 ft. There is one space that people would see as there are going through the TSA queue. This is one of the glass spaces. The remaining spaces are all on the other side after going through TSA. On the way toward the international terminal area is one of the flat wall spaces. Daniel was concerned about using this as a projection space because there tend to be ambient light and shadows on the space. It is quite a good size space though. We don’t have measurement but I suspect it is 20 ft long and the height 6-8ft. Continuing down the hallway into the terminal area there is a seating area with 3 walls surrounding the space. Each wall has glass cases. Electricity is available in each of the cases if necessary. Then down on the opposite side of the terminal there is another flat space and for the current show they had multiple canvas pieces. This space has a low ceiling compared to the others spaces. 
In additional to showing the spaces, Daniel talked about the stipend and because it is quite low he prepared me in advance. He said the stipend would $1,500. However, he said that they would handle all the shipping, handling logistics and insurance. He also said that normally there is a proposal submission process but that he would talk legal to try to get that waved. 
I also asked about timelines and basically whatever would be shown would be picked up sometime in December. And the decision on what would be shown has to be decided by August. 
We did talk about an active plotter. Based on what I saw, any plotter would have to be vertical. And with respect loading paper a roll or some other method would need to be implemented to minimize having to have a person interact with the plotter. I ask Daniel what he thought the maximum interaction with plotter would be. He thought that a maximum of once every two weeks. Although, if the staff at the airport were not involved, he seemed to think it could be more often. 
So that is kind of the summary. 
I am  putting on my thinking cap. At this time, I would prefer the glass cases. Unfortunately having a traditional projection in the cases would not be practical. However, I do see Samsung has interesting solution whereby the image is projected from the floor onto a rolled screen (see link below). Nice idea, but I rather think a more narrow system would be required for the airport cases. If we want to go that route of we’d need a solution that fits inside the case. I do think a mechanical machine would be more engaging. The projections are nice but with the nature of the world today with screens everywhere I wonder if another screen would just be another screen and would get lost. I know we don’t have much time, but I’m wondering if an unconventional solution can be found. A plotter that is more like a etch-a-sketch that doesn’t require paper.  Or one that plots on a white board that can then be erased or something similar. I’m also wondering how we might implement a way for people to have an image as a take-away. I know we don’t have much time, but what if we had an app that worked only in proximity of the display. And if they like the image being generated they could capture it on with the app in some way maybe. Thereby having their own NFT of sorts. An NFT that we would still have control over. 
We could just go with static pieces too. 
 If you want to talk more about it we can. 
Tom
https://www.samsung.com/us/televisions-home-theater/television-home-theater-accessories/televisions/the-premiere-rollable-screen-2022-vg-prsp120s-za/?cid=sem-mktg-pfs-tv-us-bing-na-06202023-141500-&ds_e=MICROSOFT-cr:0-pl:294818637-&ds_c=CN~Premiere+NB_ID~n_PR~premi_SB~tv_PH~on_KS~gc_MK~us_OB~conv_FS~lo_FF~bing_BS~vd_KM~phrase-&ds_ag=ID~n_AG~Premiere+Large_AE~mul_AT~stads_MD~h_PK~roah_PB~bing_PL~sa360_CH~search_FF~gc+phrase-&ds_k=large+room+projector&&msclkid=409a6dba89cb1e5ed9a605bb6e31d5e5&gclid=409a6dba89cb1e5ed9a605bb6e31d5e5&gclsrc=3p.ds&gad_source=7

filename: Re_ Just touching base - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2024-12-03 1456.eml
subject: Re: Just touching base
message_text:
Hi Bob and Debbie, how nice to hear from you! I was thinking of you both
last week because, yes, I went to England for the opening of Electric
Dreams and also to meet with Mila and her team at the Gazelli gallery. A
commercial sponsor might be interested in underwriting the touring of the
Whitney show. Very early stages of discussion, but they seem quite
excited. As it happened, Bre Pettis (the plotter guy) was also in London.
Is Zach still enjoying his work there?

Did you and the art survive the twin hurricanes? I think one of them hit
your part of Florida pretty hard, didn't it?

I can't remember whether you met my daughter and her fiancee at the Whitney
event. They got married last month, very lovely ceremony with a small
crowd of friends from college and their respective labs. Allegra is
finishing a tour or duty at DARPA and planning her next gig.

Last week I bought a house in Boston so I can be closer to Allegra and
Hitch. I was at the Courtauld Institute during the closing looking at the
Cezannes, but thanks to Docusign it all worked! I'll sell the Pittsburgh
place in the spring. No idea whether I'll remain as a prof. The Trust
takes so much time but it doesn't pay me anything, so I'm kinda stuck
between a rock and a hard place!

As to drawings, we have a ridiculously big stack of them in San Diego and
I'd be happy to send some (I'll need your address). I also have five from
each plotter that were signed by Christiane, Bre and me. I'll send one of
each of these if you're interested.

filename: Re_ found some of Harold's code in my "Perfume" code from 1982 - zipnpup <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2024-09-18 0952.eml
subject: RE: found some of Harold's code in my "Perfume" code from 1982
recipient:
George Legrady <glegrady@ucsb.edu>, Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>,
 "Christiane Paul, Curatorial" <christiane_paul@whitney.org>, Becky Cohen
 <beckycohenphotographer@gmail.com>
message_text:
Hi GeorgeCongrats on inadvertantly coming across your June 17, 1982 code with Harold's subroutines. This is fantastic! Thanks for sharing the details on you perfume molecule visualizer. Sounds very interesting how you used Harold's subroutines as part of your animation. It would be nice to get this running again to how Harold's routines played a roll in your 1982 code and see if there is any hints of AARON running in the background in addition to seeing what your visualizer did. So cool.
 I will confer with Paul as to what would be best. My thoughts are... For our archives I would like the scanned 20 pages as a PDF but if it is not too much trouble having both the scan and OCR would be ideal. Knowing some of the names of Harold's routines might be valuable in connecting it to the notebooks we have and the oldest code we have.
Thanks so much George
Tom

message_text:
Hi Paul,

I agree and have had lengthy conversations with Michael yesterday regarding
this as in all of our material we have always said that it was an editioned
work (as I mentioned before, even with the original selection we made had a
mix of editioned and 'unique' works to be printed - which was not flagged).
He apologised for missing this but did say that having other prints
(physical) with or without the NFT component to it, "floating around" on
the market is a "no-go".

From what I understand, all printed additional works of the selection that
was made for Sotheby's are not signed and vary in size. We could therefore
assume that these were 'reference prints' as Tom mentioned in some of his
findings and the intention of Harold's was always to publish the full
edition, but it never happened (as far as these 9 works go).

For future sales of any of these 9 works, if the need arises, we could
argue that the work will not be considered as part of this edition as it
will be reprinted posthumously and signed off by HCT. Thus, although the
image is the same, the work that will be on offer at Sotheby's is still
argued to be unique.

What do you think?
Happy to chat through over a call if easier.

Speak soon,
Mila



> Mila, I think that attestation only works if we consider others to be
> artist proofs. When did this requirement arise? It’s the first I’ve heard
> of it. In effect it precludes us from selling others, even when we know
> Harold intended the work to be editioned. I assume we can sell new
> prints but not those Harold made. It’s very restrictive and way, way too
> late to impose it now. P
>
> On Thu, Sep 26, 2024 at 8:35 AM Mila Askarova <
> m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com> wrote:
>
>> Hi,
>>
>> Sharing with you the material for final sign off!
>> (Please note this is being reviewed by Sotheby's too so there might be
>> some tweaks made to it)
>>
>> Their main concern was the uniqueness of the work. It has to be
>> identified as unique, despite the physical print saying otherwise. The way
>> around this, we suggest the wording that is found both in the press
>> release (at the bottom) and the description of the NFT: "Unique, signed
>> edition and the only known one that has been produced during the artist's
>> lifetime."
>> Are you happy with this?
>>
>> - press release
>> - description of the NFT
>> - mock NFT visual
>>
>> [image: MOCK NFT- Opensea View.png]
>>
>>
>> - mock COA
>> [image: Digital COA.png]
>>
>> My best,
>> Mila
>>

cc:

filename: Quick reply requested - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2025-03-28 1556.eml
subject: Quick reply requested
message_text:
Hi Tom, first I must apologize for asking for a quick answer: Can you have a look at this opportunity <https://schmidtsciences.smapply.io/prog/humanities_and_artificial_intelligence_virtual_institute_havi_/> from the Schmidt Sciences and let me know whether you’d like to participate in something I’ve been calling the 21st Century Catalogue Raisonne. Basically the idea is to use all we know about an artist — the art, writing, exhibitions, email, lectures, correspondence, photos etc. — to build a really thorough, organized, conversational catalogue raisonne. I’ve started work on such a thing for Harold based on some earlier work on machine reading, machine learning, knowledge curation and other stuff. Anthropic say they’re interested. We have until next week to get a 3-pager done. If they like it then we have a couple of months to write a proper proposal. 

Can you let me know if you are interested and whether I can add you as a participant, please. Many thanks, —P

filename: Harold Cohen at Christies - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2025-02-23 1255.eml
subject: Harold Cohen at Christies
message_text:
Hi Mr. Crowley, I received the email that you sent to the Harold Cohen
Trust about interviewing Harold for an NBC segment on the upcoming
Christies sale. I'm the Trustee and Harold Cohen's son. Harold died in
2016, so you won't be able to interview him. I might be able to answer
some of your questions or you might like to speak with Mila Askarova at the
Gazelli Art House in London, which represents the Trust, or with Christiane
Paul at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Cristiane curated a major
exhibition of Harold's work at the Whitney last year. I can't speak to

filename: Re_ Regarding shipper - Michael Pollard <michael@gazelliarthouse.com> - 2025-03-28 0707.eml
subject: Re: Regarding shipper
cc:
Mila Askarova <m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com>, Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>, 
	Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>, 
	Anastasia Shapovalova <anastasia@gazelliarthouse.com>, 
	George Lionel Barker <george@gazelliarthouse.com>
message_text:
Good day Tom,

Assuming you are happy with the COI, the next step is to sign the form and
return to Dietl.
This is required ahead of the collection because the document covers
elements of liability / insurance (should anything happen when they visit /
review the works) which is more in relation to what Gazelli's broker would
need to do in the event of an incident (claim within 1 year, etc.)

Once Dietl has the document they will come back to you to schedule a
convenient visit day / time for you to review all the works that are
shipping, and will return on a later date with all the necessary packing
supplies.

I'll reach out to my contact at Dietl and see if he needs any additional
information, and to check he has the latest list with all the details.

Michael.

Dear Paul,

I hope this message finds you well. I received a licensing request, details included below, to feature Harold Cohen's AARON Gijon, 2007, in an upcoming digital learning project. Before responding to this request, I wanted to check in with you to see if the Trust would rather handle this request directly, in which case I'd be happy to connect you with Cengage, or more generally to see if you are amenable to this type of project. filename: Re_ Material to sign off on - Mila Askarova <m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com> - 2024-09-26 1752.eml
subject: Re: Material to sign off on
cc:
Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>, Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>, 
	Paul Cohen <team@haroldcohentrust.org>
message_text:
Hi Tom,

Thank you so much for this.

If none of the images are exactly the same, then why do you think he
editioned them?
I've mentioned this in the other email just now too, do we know if any of
the other 'editions' of the 9 works selected were/are signed?
Paul, let me have a chat with Michael as I mentioned, will report back with
how we can navigate this as I think it is a matter of getting the wording
right so it is not misleading but also comforts both parties.
Will have a think about it but in the meantime, might something like this
be more in line with what we are trying to say? :
*Each work is a unique, signed edition with no other editions available
with an accompanying ERC-721 token.*

My best,
Mila



> Hi Mila
> It is difficult to describe what it is that AARON does/did. The imagery
> generated is unique. The print is 1 of x and there was a 2 of x and 3 of x
> in some cases. So there maybe x of x instances of this uniqueness. Each
> work AARON generates is certainly unique in that AARON by Cohen's coded
> design does not generate the same work more once. It is unique in that it
> is signed 1 of x whereas no other print is signed 1 of x. The series is
> special in that we have never sold the digital image let alone the digital
> + print together. I'm not sure if including AARON in the text is
> appropriate but like I mentioned Harold's coded design of AARON assures us
> that AARON did not and cannot generate the same likeness of this same image
> even we ran it billions of times it would not generate this image again.
> The wording is a bit tricky because we may another print produced in his
> lifetime but it is certainly not signed as 1 of x.
>
> I am not in a disagreement of the use of unique as that is an inherent
> feature if AARON. I would like a slightly different wording with "only
> known" as all of our picks were chosen specifically because they were not
> the only known one. I do agree with the uniqueness use I am just not sure
> how to resolve the conflicting message in such a short sentence. But I will
> think about it.
>
>
> Tom
>
>
>

message_text:
Hi Mila
As I mentioned previously, the V&A has one of Cohen's 2003 print. Here is the link
https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O114804/0305-08-print-cohen-harold/
The text they provide claims that the title is 0305-08 and that it is copy number 2/3 and that this work is signed.
It has has text on the the webpage that readsCohen insists that display labels and image credits for prints produced by AARON should read "Digital print by AARON, a computer program written by Harold Cohen". 
And the accession number isE.264-2005

 I am looking to see what other information we have regarding additional signed edition prints of the 9 Sotheby picks. As the V&S example was the easiest to find, I am sharing this with you now to let you know that there is at least one verifiable instance of an additional signed print in the collection of the Sotheby 9 picks. I will now start looking for digital documents of additional evidence. Physical printed documents will have to wait until tomorrow when I return to the studio. 
Tom

cc:

message_text:
Hi George,Thanks so much for reminding me about the Machine Paintings! I will make the appropriate corrections. I have a question. We have this big 9x15 foot painting (i23-4425) from 1968 in the DOT style — see attached. I unrolled it last year to inventory and it looks gorgeous. But it stunk to high heaven and was causing the other works to stink. So I rolled it backup rolling it in heavy paper, then rolled it with plastic and taped it up. I then stored it in the spray room which has ventilation to the outside and is away from all the other artworks. I don’t know what happened to this work but I am wondering if it can be saved and/or if it should be saved. The artwork is so large I had to use the pan feature to capture the entire image. This means the wavy edges are not wavy they are straight. I am wondering if this is something we should send at this time? Of course it would need to be sent with care. Let me know your thoughts.
Tom
 On Thursday, January 9, 2025 at 02:16:54 AM PST, George Lionel Barker <george@gazelliarthouse.com> wrote: 

 Hey Tom, 

Many thanks for sending this over, and for all your hard work getting it together. 
I appreciate that this is a work in progress, so maybe it will be updated, but there are Painting Machine works included on your list that are already with us in London. I think the attached document I sent earlier is what you have in California to ship? 
With warmest wishes, 
George Barker 

GAZELLI ART HOUSE
LONDONQuiet Motion
BAKU Parallel Worlds: Chris Levine, Michael Takeo Magruder, Marshmallow Laser Feast, Elnara Nasirli, Recycle Group, Nye Thompson

If you are not an intended recipient, you are hereby notified that you have either received this message in error or through interception, and that any review, use, distribution, copying or disclosure of this message and/or its attachments or parts thereof is strictly prohibited and is subject to criminal and civil penalties with appropriate national legislation.
ᐧ


Dear Gazelli Team,Below is a link to the 2025 Artwork Shipment List. This list is a work in progress and not complete. I ran into a problem with some of the portrait paintings dates. I am not sure why but some of them have the wrong dates so I am reviewing all of them. I did notice some other inconsistancies in the artlogic document compared to the original notes sometime ago but have not done a comprehensive review as of yet. In any case, I am plugging away at creating the list you can see most of it here. I need to move some items around to access some additional works which may be approximately 4 more items. Currently there are 54 items to be shipped. That is quite of few and I want to make sure everything it correct so I appreciate your patience as it will take a bit longer to complete. I do have most of the measurements that were not in the original artlogic doc George sent and hope to have all the measurements by Thursday or at least an estimated measurement as I suspect the measurements are important to the shipper. 
Here is the link. If you are unable to view this please let me know.https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/11MqbW2pAIPfUA4YNC6AHWu09PPzyM20-YvIF8nedKNs/edit?usp=sharing

Tom

filename: Re_ found some of Harold's code in my "Perfume" code from 1982 - Christiane Paul <Christiane_Paul@whitney.org> - 2024-09-18 0949.eml
subject: Re: found some of Harold's code in my "Perfume" code from 1982
recipient:
George Legrady <glegrady@ucsb.edu>, Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>,
	Becky Cohen <beckycohenphotographer@gmail.com>
message_text:
Thanks so much for looking into it and tracking down the code, George! I think it would be most relevant to the studio, but I'm also always interested in having the information for my own research and records.

As to credits, the ones for software usually don't go to that level of detail (e.g. on tombstone labels), but I think it would be nice to either credit everyone who contributed to the code or make a distinction between animation / subroutines with individual credit wherever it's appropriate.

Thanks again, hope you're all well!
Christiane

Christiane Paul

Curator of Digital Art

Whitney Museum of American Art
99 Gansevoort Street
New York, NY 10014

Cc: Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com>

filename: Re_ Virtual introduction Daniel Dennert - Dennert Daniel <ddennert@san.org> - 2025-04-04 1535.eml
subject: RE: Virtual introduction Daniel Dennert
message_text:
Thanks so much for connecting us, Christiane! Moving you to BCC.

Paul and Tom, nice to meet you—and thank you for the quick response. As Christiane mentioned, I’m the curator for the arts program at San Diego International Airport. One of my roles is organizing temporary exhibitions that showcase contemporary art from the region. These are themed exhibitions that bring together a variety of artists in dialogue around a central idea.

We’re currently developing concepts for upcoming shows, and as more San Diego-based artists explore the use of AI as a creative partner, we thought it would be timely to feature that subject. Given Harold Cohen’s pioneering contributions to the field—and his connection to San Diego—we wanted to reach out about potential ways to incorporate his work or legacy as a thread in the exhibition.

I’d love to set up a time to talk. Would you be available next week—either Thursday between 3:30–5:00 PM or Friday after 1:00 PM?

Thanks so much,
Daniel

Daniel Dennert
Curator, Arts Program | Customer Experience
Mobile 619.952.3787
ddennert@san.org<mailto:ddennert@san.org>
ARTS.SAN.ORG<https://linkprotect.cudasvc.com/url?a=http%3a%2f%2farts.san.org%2f&c=E,1,T2nJnilZgtgYMzIy6LF_LRAfnMbImec5WUiaBBjFAG1-q34i9mdeBH21extv6JItyYGkvxxBCQDHsQTsQZWB7TxH06FzWh4lQS2j0v41c-MpWU8,&typo=1>

filename: two things - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2024-10-21 1258.eml
subject: two things
message_text:
Hi Tom, just a couple of followup things from my meeting with Mila this
morning.

I understand that you inventoried roughly 4000 works and there are still
some to be done. Knowing that it'll take a while to do the remaining
inventory, what do you think of the following idea: Could you make a rough
classification of what remains to be inventoried? Here's my thinking: We
need a five-year plan for raising prices, so we need to know the whole
inventory, but we're most concerned about high-valued works, and
particularly how many we have (i.e., rarity). If you knew, for example,
that we have 20 paintings in a particular category, then for the purpose of
strategic planning we wouldn't need to inventory them immediately, because
just knowing that there are 20 would be hugely helpful. What do you think?

The other topic is storage. We're both concerned about storing work in the
house simply because the house is old and not very secure. Again wrt
high-value work we could ship more of it to London (or New York if Mila
does in fact open a gallery there) or to local safe storage in San Diego.
What do you think?

cc:
Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com>, Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>, 
	Askarova Norton Mila <m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com>, Chow Natalia <natalia@verisart.com>
message_text:
Robert, I'm sorry it's a pain but yes, I think our best path is the one
you suggest.

This has been a surprisingly rich learning experience (how's that for a
positive spin!) particularly this most recent issue. It is sure to happen
again, or something similar that could cause a token to be withdrawn, so I
wonder whether there's any general method to deal with these cases. For
example, is there any notion of a provisional NFT or does that undermine
the whole idea of NFTs. When I buy a house, I sign one contract saying
that I intend to buy it, but this isn't the contract that formalizes
ownership. That comes later, after various inspections are passed.

message_text:
Likewise, thanks so much for the introduction, Paul!
I'd also be happy to answer any questions (you find information about the Whitney Museum exhibition here<https://whitney.org/exhibitions/harold-cohen-aaron>).
[https://whitneymedia.org/assets/image/829164/large_RS73495_Harold-Cohen-AARON-for-KCat-2021_web.jpg]<https://whitney.org/exhibitions/harold-cohen-aaron>
Harold Cohen: AARON | Whitney Museum of American Art<https://whitney.org/exhibitions/harold-cohen-aaron>
This exhibition traces the evolution of Harold Cohens AARON, the earliest artificial intelligence (AI) program for artmaking. Leaving behind his practice as an established painter in London, Cohen (19282016) conceived the software in the late 1960s at the University of California, San Diego, and named it AARON in the early 1970s.
whitney.org
All best,
Christiane

Curator of Digital Art

Whitney Museum of American Art

New York, NY 10014

message_text:
Hi Tom,

Great to hear from you.

I've attached the shipping document for the 18 Figurative works on canvas
that fit within your 6 parameters. I have attached a list which has images,
plus the link here:
https://privateviews.artlogic.net/2/f5fcb1f56f9ce5a013b84a/
<https://privateviews.artlogic.net/2/f5fcb1f56f9ce5a013b84a/>.

Not to distract from the shipping project, but can you also please check if
there are any additional works with you that fit your parameters that are
not listed here?

Regarding the Painting Machine works. We have a total of 18 in London. This
list includes sold works, plus two that are consigned from Tom Gruber.
Here's the list: https://privateviews.artlogic.net/2/237bf664d6efbf6f724c20/

According to your document 'Preliminary WIP', you have 17 works remaining
in the HCT collection? They are TCM5, TCM7, TCM8, TCM9, TCM10, TCM12,
TCM13, TCM18, TCM24, TCM25, TCM27 (signed and framed), TCM101, TCM102,
TCM104, TCM105, TCM106, TCM108. I have put together a document with the
images and titles attached.

Can you please include these works with the shipment of the figurative
canvas too? Our timeframe would be in the early New Year, if possible?

As always, we are here to help, so please do get in touch with any
outstanding questions or concerns.

wrote:

>
> Hi Everyone,
> I just want us to be in agreement as to what constitutes as figurative

filename: Re_ Christie's - Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2025-01-29 0050.eml
subject: Re: Christie's
cc:
Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com>, 
	Harold Cohen Trust <aaron@aaronshome.com>, 
	Mila Askarova <m.askarova@gazelliarthouse.com>, 
	Paul Cohen <team@haroldcohentrust.org>
message_text:
Dear Pegah,

I was unaware of the upcoming Christie's auction as I was probably not in the loop. No matter, I will do what I can with the allotted time available. Understanding does change over time and therefore this reply is based on the current understanding. I attached a memo Harold wrote in 1993. His memo addresses the work from the same time period as the i23-3758 up for auction at Christie’s. These clarifications regarding Harold’s work tend to be tricky. One of the problems with the word “Series” in English is that series is both singular and plural. Please keep that in mind. 

In the memo below, Harold writes about two main phases of AARON, Primitive and Knowledgable. The first of these two Harold called “Primitive”. Time wise Primitive works are Pre-1980. The second phase he called “Knowledgable" (Post-1980). The Knowledgable phase is the one that i23-3758 belongs to. According to his memo, 1980s can basically be cut in half. The first half (1980-1985) Harold does not name but I will call Early Knowledge. The second half Harold called is the “provision of a physical ambience” or I will called Ambience for short.  And 1985 is basically transitional. In 1985 Harold begins the transition by developing human figures in motion. This is quickly followed by him adding Ambience for the human figures. First we see Statues of Liberty figures, then the Athletes and the Bathers. And then later we see works like i23-3758.

In his memo Harold refers to AARON as having the knowledge to generate anything from a quasi-daisy to a quasi oak-tree. A collection of these qausi-plants becomes the ambience. He claims that this knowledge was capable of providing for a very large number of drawings and that this group was referred to as “Eden Series.” Unfortunately, it is difficult to know if series is singular or plural. He then says that some friends refer to these works as "Yuppies in the Jungle." 

Based on Harold’s memo, I rather think the two terms “Eden Series” and “Yuppies in the Jungle” are interchangeable. However, in the studio where items are labelled, there is a specific group of works identified as Yuppies in the Jungle or YIJ. Also in the studio there are multiple groups of works labelled as “Jungle Drawings.”  Not to add to the confusion, there is also a (2013) painting titled Eden. This later work is one of a group of works where Harold revisited earlier works. 

So, based on the way I interpret what Harold wrote, the i23-3758 is both from the Eden Series (where series is plural noun) and from the Jungle Drawing series (series as a singular noun). Eden seems to be more of an umbrella group of multiple series of works. And where Jungle Drawings is a subset series of Eden. 

This is the best reply I can provide at this time. Let me know if you have any questions,

Tom

filename: Re_ Dietl Shipper - Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2025-04-07 0517.eml
subject: Re: Dietl Shipper
message_text:
Hi Paul,I sent a reply but didn’t look like it went through so I will try again. I needed to reply to Michael Pollard of Gazelli regarding this. Looks like I didn’t cc you so here is what I sent to Michael. 

Hi Michael,

Regarding Dietl, I am a bit conflicted on some issues. One, when they refer to “Customer” exactly who is that? Is Gazelli the customer or HCT? OR jointly? If it is HCT, then there are multiple places in the document whereby HCT needs to agree to unspecified terms and that makes me feel a bit uneasy due to the value of the shipment and since we have never dealt with Dietl before. And since we have no proven track record with them. 

One example of agreeing to unspecified terms is in part 4a. It reads, “Customer understands that the terms and conditions under which DIS’ services are provided are subject to change. Customer is advised to take note of the most current terms and conditions which are posted on DIS’ web site and which are also available to Customer upon request. Customer agrees that the posted terms and conditions on DIS’ website on the date of a shipment will apply to that shipment and govern the parties’ obligations.”  At a minimum we need to review the most current terms. However, even the current terms are subject to change until the date of the shipment. 

And part 1 reads, “Customer understands that the terms and conditions of the storage receipts of warehousemen, and contracts of carriage of air, land and/or ocean carriers that DIS retains will apply to Customer as if Customer had entered into those contracts itself. “ We don’t know these terms in advance  and is another example of agreeing to unspecified terms. 

Also in part 1 it reads, Customer warrants that the goods are properly marked, addressed, and packaged to withstand any contemplated method of transport. This is currently not the case, only marking for identification purposes is done.

In section 1A it reads, DIS WILL ONLY HONOR INSURANCE CLAIMS WHEN FEES ARE CHARGED ON AN INVOICE AND PAID TO DIS FOR INSURANCE COVERAGE ON THE SHIPMENT IN WHICH THE CLAIM OCCURRED.  I understand and have received your notice regarding insurance with Lloyd’s of London. My concern is that the way this reads, it sounds like if we do need to make an insurance claim, Dietl will not recognize a 3rd party insurance and therefore under no obligation to be forthcoming with any requests related to a claim with Lloyd’s of London. If so, is that problematic when making a claim them?

In section 1C it reads, Customer warrants that it shall consider DIS’ Customer Supply Chain Security Recommendations as posted on DIS’ website. We need the link to this so we can review it.

In section 1D it read,  Customer agrees to inspect its shipment upon delivery and give prompt notice of any loss or damage within 5 days of delivery for air or ground shipments and within 3 days of

delivery for ocean shipments.  If HCT is the “Customer”, how do we go about this inspection? 

With respect to section 2E “DIS GIVEN A LIEN ON GOODS FOR UNPAID CHARGES”. This goes back to who is the “Customer” and thereby who is the responsible party for payments?

Tom

 Hi Tom,

CEO & Founder

www.gazelliarthouse.com
+44 (0) 207 491 8816 / +994 (0) 12 498 1230



Dear Paul & Mila,
Below are two links. One is to the Providence + Metadata document. The other is a link to the file folder to make the NFTs. I know that previously I sent the files for the NFTs but if possible please use these because I used these files to extract the metadata. While most of them are the same, there are some slight differences. So if possible, please use the ones in the link below.

I was not sure how to word some of the Providence events so if necessary you can change it so long as the events are intact. I was not sure how to word what "aa" files are. Internally, I typically refer to them as AARON Vector files but the more I thought about it the more I realized that AARON vector files are really the generation before where the vector (black line drawing file) and color file were two different files. The aa files have additional information on how to make the artwork besides just vectors. Keeping that in mind I used "AARON Artwork descriptor file" instead of AARON Artwork vector file. I would prefer to reserve the term AARON Artwork vector file for the drawing files that truly are lists of vectors.
As mentioned earlier, all of the jpegs were made by Harold at a later date. I found those dates and included them on the second line. The last line I listed that the file name was changed. We don't exactly know how he created the jpegs so I had to be vague about the process and simply put the date followed by, "Harold Cohen completes jpeg conversion, names file" then put the file name.
There was one jpeg that was corrupted. We currently do not have a way to convert aa files into jpegs. Fortunately, we have a Postscript file of the same work that was generated within one minute of the original aa file. I used the postscript file to make a jpeg file. So in this instance, there is no aa file listed since it was not directly involved in the making the jpg. I included my name as the one who made the conversion in case that is relevant. But can be removed with no skin off my back. In the case of the file name changes, I simply put HCT changed the names.
Regarding the Metadata, some files have much more metadata available than others. I chose to limit some of the metadata so as to keep the group basically the same. 

There was much data to enter by hand. I have checked it multiple times but after a good night sleep will check it one last time. If you find any inconsistencies, feel free to correct or ask me about it, Tom

Link to files to be used as NFTs
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1k-i05lGnEvYi8SNKzi3MAITAVvzMeTAQ?usp=sharing

filename: Re_ Trust Website Update - Paul Cohen <paulrcohen@gmail.com> - 2024-10-15 1602.eml
subject: Re: Trust Website Update
cc: kanoko nishi 西鹿乃子 <littledeerofthewest@googlemail.com>,  Allegra Cohen <allegra.ab.cohen@gmail.com>
message_text:
Hi Daniel, it looks great! I look forward to iterating with you on little
adjustments but overall I think Harold would be thrilled and proud of it.

Can I ask two things, please. First, please invoice the HCT for the work.
Second, if you are willing to continue on the project, then I'd like to
have a zoom call with you and Sascha, who is CTO at Verisart. Briefly the
idea is to publish two catalogs raisonne, one a handsome print volume that
doesn't include everything, the other an exhaustive, searchable listing
accessible from the HCT web site. The question is whether Verisart can
serve records to the web site easily. If so, then 1) everything can be on
chain, 2) we can augment Verisart records with information they cannot
currently handle, such as Tom's provenance notes or facsimiles of
exhibition catalogs. I think we should run a little experiment to see
whether Verisart can serve a record when requested from the HCT website
client. I might also be totally off-base about the right way to get the
functionality we want! If you are interested, can you suggest some times
we might chat with Sascha, keeping in mind the eight-hour time difference.

Beautiful work, thank you!

message_text:
Hi Paul,

Great to hear from you.

Yes, we are all on the same page with regards to Mila's idea of pricing the
medium-sized works on canvas in relation to their 'quality'. The four works
I highlighted would be priced at £150,000, and the first 'batch' we can
sell.

Regarding the Art Fairs strategy, I think the best route forward is to
decide on the selection depending on which fairs we get into. Currently we
are in the process of applying for/waiting to be invited to, both Armory
NYC and Dallas. So we can make a selection once we get in? But either way,
are we agreed that the four paintings I highlighted are ok to be priced at
£150,000?

Regarding Tom Gruber, we are getting a good deal if we buy his work, but it
is a purchase decision, so I will leave it up to you both.

The Artsy alert is in relation to a group show we have curated over the
Christmas and New Year period called 'Quiet Motion'. We have priced the 60s
work at £100,000. The pricing is aligned with the 60s canvases we showed
during 'Refactoring'.

Let me know if that's all clear? We're really excited to see what Tom will
send over in the roll!

With warmest wishes,

George Barke

Harold made work continuously for roughly 70 years! Much of the work

filename: Re_ Harold in Texas - Thomas Machnik <zipnpup@yahoo.com> - 2025-02-28 1422.eml
subject: Re: Harold in Texas
message_text:
George,This is what I think. At first glance I would say, the photo of the work initialed by Harold as "HC 72" may have been signed by Harold in 1972, but it is highly unlikely it would have been plotted in 1972. 1972 was characterized by plotted Maze drawings. Drawings plotted on his first generation of plotters. Again at first glance I would put this in 1969 and possibly a transition work from away from Contours. 
Upon second glance, because it is initialed and had not formally signed it, in a sense has a different meaning to Harold. So I need to think outside of the box on this one. For example, I recall seeing pages and pages of notes in Harold’s notebooks of number drawn in the style similar to the ones in the “HC 72.”
